maintainer merge

bors d+
Does dot notation on `RingCon` not already work out of the box? by which I mean that without your new lemma I would expect `t.sub` to automatically expand to `t.toAddCon.sub`
Ah maybe it proves `t.toAddCon (a - c) (b - d)`... Mind checking?

The following gave an error
```lean
example  {S : Type*} [AddGroup S] [Mul S] (t : RingCon S) : true := by
  have := t.sub

/-
invalid field 'sub', the environment does not contain 'RingCon.sub'
  t
has type
  RingCon S
-/
```

```suggestion
protected lemma listSum {ι S : Type*} [AddCommMonoid S] [Mul S]
```
and below
This only needs to be an `AddMonoid`.
thanks

```suggestion
lemma op_iff {c : RingCon R} {x y : Rᵐᵒᵖ} : c.op x y ↔ c y.unop x.unop := Iff.rfl
```

```suggestion
The congruences of a ring `R` biject to the congruences of the opposite ring `Rᵐᵒᵖ`.
```

```suggestion
def opOrderIso : RingCon R ≃o RingCon Rᵐᵒᵖ where
```
Does this hold without associativity? Using only `[Mul M] [One M]`.

Gonna copy my comment from another PR which I've closed.
"Technically, [this does not need associativity]. If we really wanted to generalize, we should have api for a product over a binary tree (or free magma). I do have a feeling that mathlib is using lists and multisets for things that are morally free monoids and free commutative monoids, but that might be a refactor for another day."
`List.prod_cons` requires `Monoid M`. I think removing associativity here means we need to remove associativity at `List.prod_cons` as well.

As `prod` is defined with `foldl`, `prod_cons` requires associativity. You would need to unfold `prod` and work with `foldl` directly to prove this without associativity. I would argue this generalization requires more work and is outside of the scope of this PR.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/Congruence): split `RingCon` construction and add some constructions

source.title: feat(RingTheory/Congruence): interpret `RingCon` as two sided ideals
